articles.headline: Luster Dims For a Public Microlender
articles.snippet: SKS Microfinance last week reported its first loss as a public company as loan repayments fell.
articles.abstract: SKS Microfinance last week reported its first loss as a public company as loan repayments fell.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — After SKS Microfinance, India’s largest microlender, completed its initial public offering last August, its shares quickly shot up 50 percent. Financial analysts charted rosy forecasts about the firm’s future.

articles.headline: Killings and Rumors Unsettle a Libyan City
articles.snippet: The deaths of former government officials in Benghazi, the center of the Libyan resistance, appear to be rooted in vengeance and have raised the specter of a death squad.
articles.abstract: The deaths of former government officials in Benghazi, the center of the Libyan resistance, appear to be rooted in vengeance and have raised the specter of a death squad.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — Three weeks ago, a traveler spotted a man’s body in the farmland on this city’s outskirts, shot twice in the head with his hands and feet bound. He had disappeared earlier that day, after visiting a market.

articles.headline: Hip Makers Told to Study More Data
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration ordered all producers of a popular category of artificial hip to study the implants, which have been linked to severe health effects in some patients.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration ordered all producers of a popular category of artificial hip to study the implants, which have been linked to severe health effects in some patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an unusual move, the Food and Drug Administration has ordered all producers of a popular category of artificial hip to undertake studies of the implants, which have been linked to high early failure rates and severe health effects in some patients.

articles.headline: Rent or Buy, a Matter of Lifestyle
articles.snippet: The relative merits are closer than they have been since the housing bubble began inflating almost a decade ago.
articles.abstract: The relative merits are closer than they have been since the housing bubble began inflating almost a decade ago.

articles.headline: For Microsoft, Skype Opens Vast New Market in Telecom
articles.snippet: In agreeing to pay $8.5 billion to buy Skype, Microsoft is embracing a technology that is transforming the way people communicate at home and at work.
articles.abstract: In agreeing to pay $8.5 billion to buy Skype, Microsoft is embracing a technology that is transforming the way people communicate at home and at work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft has peered into the future, and placed a bet that people the world over want to stay in touch with someone anytime and anywhere — preferably at no cost.

articles.headline: Neo-Nazi Father Is Killed; Son, 10, Steeped in Beliefs, Is Accused
articles.snippet: Jeff Hall’s young children were raised in a home where white supremacism was embraced. Now one of them has been charged with his murder.
articles.abstract: Jeff Hall’s young children were raised in a home where white supremacism was embraced. Now one of them has been charged with his murder.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The day before he allegedly shot his father, the sandy-haired 10-year-old boy showed off a prized possession to a visitor. It was a thin leather belt emblazoned with a silver insignia of the Nazi SS.

articles.headline: Federal Retreat on Bigger Loans Rattles Housing
articles.snippet: Planned cuts in the size of a mortgage that can be backed by the federal government may hurt upscale housing markets in high-cost states like New York and California.
articles.abstract: Planned cuts in the size of a mortgage that can be backed by the federal government may hurt upscale housing markets in high-cost states like New York and California.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTEREY, Calif. — By summer’s end, buyers and sellers in some of the country’s most upscale housing markets are slated to lose one their biggest benefactors: the deep pockets of the federal government. In this seaside community of pricey homes, the dread of yet another housing shock is already spreading.

articles.headline: A Social Networking Device for Smokers
articles.snippet: Blu, the maker of electronic cigarettes, has developed sensors that will let users know when other e-smokers are nearby.
articles.abstract: Blu, the maker of electronic cigarettes, has developed sensors that will let users know when other e-smokers are nearby.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies have started adding the ability to communicate wirelessly to an increasing range of devices, like tablet computers, cars and refrigerators.

articles.headline: Japan Ponders Its New Normal
articles.snippet: With its status quo gone, the country is looking to what kind of economy it wants to cultivate for the future.
articles.abstract: With its status quo gone, the country is looking to what kind of economy it wants to cultivate for the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISHINOMAKI, Japan — Its factory wiped out by the tsunami, a maker of vital parts for smartphones says it will move production overseas.

articles.headline: Taking Airport, Rebels in Libya Loosen Noose
articles.snippet: Taking control of the airport in Libya’s third-largest city was a major rebel victory in the conflict.
articles.abstract: Taking control of the airport in Libya’s third-largest city was a major rebel victory in the conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISURATA, Libya — Rebels in the contested western city of Misurata stormed the city’s airport on Wednesday afternoon, swarming over the grounds from the south and east and reclaiming it from the military of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
